sect1.title: Installing kubectl

tip.title: Installing kubectl on non-SUSE OS
tip.para: If you are using an operating system other than &sle; or &opensuse; please consult the installation instructions from the &kube; project.

important.para: To use kubectl to connect to a local machine you must do against the &kube; master node.

sect1.para: &kube; requires the use of kubectl for many tasks. You can perform most of these actions while logged in to an SSH session on the master node of your &productname; cluster.
One key exception is the use of kubectl proxy this requires kubectl to be installed on your local machine to act as a proxy between the local workstation and the remote cluster.

step.para: Go to the Virtualization:containers repository and find the version of &sle;/&opensuse; you are using.
Click the "Go to download repository" underneath your version.
Copy the URL to the repository from the URL bar of your browser. This is the location you will add as repository information in zypper.
Open a terminal on your local machine add a repository to zypper:
You will have to trust the key signature for the repository to continue.
Verify that kubectl was installed and is configured correctly:

important.title: Technology Preview
important.para: Even though you can install and use the community &kube; dashboard, &productname; currently fully supports only &dashboard;.

listitem.para: You need to have Heapster version 1.3.0 or later installed on the cluster.
&suse; recommends Helm version 2.7.2+ and kubectl version 1.9.0+.
kubectl needs to be installed on the local machine and configured to talk to the remote Kubernetes API (CaaSP Master node).

step.para: Connect to any cluster node using SSH.
Visit http://127.0.0.1:8081/ in your browser. You will be greeted with by a welcome page containing a dialog to configure authentication.

Now you may visit the dashboard at https://WORKER_NODE_ADDRESS:NODE_PORT in your browser from outside of your cluster.
